Description: Dome-shaped weight carved from light grey mottled dark grey hard stone; carinated sub-domed type; of truncated conical shape with flat base, sides sloping out to top and very slightly convex top, almost flat; top and underside present roundish shallow depression, and edges of base quite damaged: it indicates its reuse as a tool, such hammer or grinder.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Dome-shaped weights are very close to the cupcake-shaped ones; they just do not show a sharp edge, or strong carination. Such type, especially the one made out of basalt, is one of the most common weights found in Naukratis, and elsewhere in Egypt (Petrie 1886, Pl. XXIII, “sub-domed” type; Cour-Marty 1990, 25, fig. 3, fig. 13). Already present in the Old Kingdom, this type is particularly common on Late Period sites in the Delta (Cour-Marty 1990, 25-26, fig. 26). Dome-shaped weights are more often associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples, like with this example; however a lighter unit, around 8g, is also noticed and could correspond to other standards such as the Near Eastern shekel or the Greek stater (Cour-Marty 1990, 24-25, fig. 22-24; Kroll 2003, 317; Gerritt van Alfen, P. 2002, 184, n. 654). The Egyptian standard kedet is nonetheless the most used standard in Naukratis (Petrie 1926, 14; Cour-Marty 1990, fig. 25). The original weight was ca. 185 g (loss of 5% about), so 2 debens.
